editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: The first and second partes of King Edward the Fourth. Containing his mery pastime with the tanner of Tamworth, as also his loue to faire Mistrisse Shoare, her great promotion, fall and miserie, and lastly the lamentable death of both her and her husband. Likewise the besieging of London, by the bastard Falconbridge, and the valiant defence of the same by the Lord Maior and the citizens. As it hath diuers times beene publikely played by the Right Honorable the Earle of Derbie his seruants.
titleStmt.author: Heywood, Thomas, d. 1641.

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Michigan, Digital Library Production Service

keywords.term: Edward, -- IV, -- King of England, -- 1442-1483 -- Drama.

div.head: The first and second parts of King Edward the fourth.

argument.p: Containing his merry pastime with the tanner of Tamwoorth, as also his love to fair mistress Shore, her great promotion, fall and misery, and lastly the lamentable death of both her and her husband.

div.stage: Enter King Edward, the Duchess of York, the Queen, the lord Howard, and sir Thomas Sellinger.

sp.speaker: Duchess.
sp.l: Son, I tell ye you have done you know not what:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I have married a woman, else I am deceived mother.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Married a woman? married indeed,
Here is a marriage that befits a King:
It is no matudile it was done in haste,
Here is a bridal and with hell to boot,
You have made work?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Faith mother some we have indeed, but ere long you shall see us make work for an heir apparent I doubt not, nay, nay, come-come, gods will what chiding still

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O God that e'er I ‚óède to see this day.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: By my faith mother, I hope you shall see the night too, and in the morning I will be bold to ‚óèld you to the christning grandmother, and godmother to a prince of Wales, tut mother, 'tis a stirring world.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Have you sent Warwick into France for this?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No by my faith mother I sent Warwick into France for another, but this by chance being nearer hand, and coming in the way I cannot tell how, we concluded, and now (As you see) are going about to get a young King.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: But tell me son how will you answer this?
Is't possible your rash unlawful act,
Should not breed mortal hate betwixt the realms
What may the French King think when he shall hear
That whilst you send to entreat about his daughter,
Basely to take a subject of your own?
What may the Princess Bona think of this?
Our noble cousin Warwick that great lord,
That center-shaking thunderclap of war,
That like a colum propped the house of York:
And boar our white rose bravely in his top,
When he shall hear his embassage abuser,
In this but made an instrument by you,
I know his soul will blush within his bosom,
And shame will sit in scarlet on his brew,
To have his honor touched with this foul blesh
Son, son I tell you that is done by you,
Which yet the child that is unborn shall rue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
‚óèsh mother you are deceived, all true subjects shall have cause to thank God, to have their King born of a true English woman, I tell you it was never well since we matched with strangers, so our children have been still like chickens of the half kind but where the rock and the hen be both of one breed, there is like to be birds of the game: heare you mother, hear you, had I gone to it by fortune, I ‚óèd made your sons George and Dick to have stood gaping after the crown: this wench mother is a widow, and hath made proof of her valour, and for any thing I know, I am as like to do the deed as John grey her husband was, I had rather the people prayed to bless mine heir, then selide me an heir: hold your peace, if you can see, there was never mother had a to warder son, why cousin Howard and
Tom Sellinger heard you ever such a coil about a wife?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: My sovereign lord with patience bear her 'splain
Your princely mother's zeal is like a river,
That from the free abundance of the waters,
Breaks out into this inundation,
From her abundant care this rage proceeds,
O'er swollen with the extremity of love.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My lord, my lord, avoid a woman's humour,
If you resist this tumour of her will,
Here you shall have her dwell upon this passion,
Until she lade and dull our ears again:
Seem you but sorry for what you have done,
And straight she'll put the finger in the eye,
With comfort now, since it cannot be helped:
But make you show to justify the act
If ever other language in her lips,
Then out upon it, it is abominable, I dare be hanged,
Say any thing it makes no matter what,
Than thus be wearied with a woman's chat.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ay, ay, you are the spaniels of the court,
And thus you fawn and soothe your wanton King,
But Edward hadst thou prized thy majesty,
Thou never wouldst have stained thy princely state,
With the base leavings of a subject's bed:
Nor born the blemish of her bigamy.
A widow, is't not a goodly thing?
Gray's children come ask blessing of the King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay I beseech your grace my lady York,
Even as you are a Princess and a widow,
Think not so meanly of my widowhood,
A spotless virgin came I first to grey,
With him I ‚óèude a true and faithful wife:
And since his high imperial majesty,
Hath pleased to bless my poor deiected state
With the high sovereign title of his Queen,
I here protest before the host of heaven,
I came as chaste a widow to his bed,
As when a virgin I to grey was wed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Come, come have done, now have you chid enough, God's foot, we were as merry ere she came, as any people in Christendom, I with the mistress, and these with the maids: only we have no fiddlers at our feast, but mother you have made a fit of mirth: welcome to Grafton mother, by my troth you are even just come as I wished you here, let us go to supper, and in charity give us your blessing ere we go to bed.

sp.speaker: Du‚óèc.
sp.l: O Edward, Edward, fly and leave this place,
Wherein poor gllie King thou art enchanted,
This is her dam of Bedford's work her mother,
That hath bewitched thee Edward my poor child,
Dishonour not the princes of thy land,
To make the them kneel with reverence at her feet,
That ere thou dost empale with sovereignty,
The‚óè would have scorned to have looked upon,
There's no such difference twixt the greatest peer,
And the poor silliest kitchen maid that lives,
A‚óèls bet wirt thy worthiness and hers.

sp.speaker: Q‚óèee.
sp.l: I do confess it, yet my lady York,
My mother is a Duchess as you are,
A Princess born, the Duke of Bedford's wife,
And as you ‚óèno, a daughter and a sister,
Unto the royal blood of Burgundy.
But you cannot so basely think on me,
As I do think of these vain worldly titles,
God from soul my sin as far divide.
As I am far from boasting in this pride,

sp.speaker: Selling.
sp.l: Madam, she is the mirror of her kind,
Had she but so much spleen as hath a gnat,,
Her spirits would startle to abide your taunts,
She is a saint, and madam you blaspheme,
To wrong so sweet a lady.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou art a minion and a flatterer.

sp.speaker: Sellin.
sp.l: Madam but that you are my sovereign's mother,
I would let you know you wrong a gentleman,

sp.speaker: Howard.
sp.l: Good cousin Sellinger have patience,
Her grace's rage by too much violence,
Hath spent itself already into ‚óère:
Dear madam I beseeth you on my knee,
Tender that loving kindness to the Queen,
That I dare swear she doth in soul to you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Well said good coz, I pray thee make them friends, why how now Bess, what weep? nay then I'll chide you: what sudden news comes by this messenger?

div.stage: Enter a messenger.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: My sovereign lord, the bastard Falconbridge,
Of late hath stirred rebellion in the South,
Encouraging his forces to deliver,
King Henry late deposed out of the tower,
To him the malcontented commons flock,
From every part of Sussex, Kent, and Esier,
His army waxed twenty thousand strong.
And as it is supposed by circumstance,
Mean to take London, if not well defended.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Well let this Phaeton that is mounted thus,
Look he sit surely, or by England's George,
I'll break his neck, this is no new evasion,
I surely thought that one day I should see,
That bastard falcon take his wings to mount,
Into our eagle airy, methought I saw,
Black discontent sit ever on his brow,
And now I see I calculated well,
Good cousin Howard, and Tom Sellinger,
This night we'll spend in feast and jollity,
With our new Queen, and our beloved mother,
Tomorrow you shall have commission,
To raise up power against this haughty rebel:
Sirrah depart not till you know our pleasure,
You shall convey us letters back to London,
unto the mayor, recorder, and our friends,
Is supper ready? come by my bonny Bess,
Welcome mother, we are all your guests.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Falconbridge with his troops marching, spicing, smoke, Chub, and others.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hold drum,

sp.speaker: 1. Spi.
sp.l: Hold drum and be hanged,

sp.speaker: 2. Smoke.
sp.p: Hold drum hold, peace then ho, silence to the 3 proclamation.

sp.speaker: 1. Spi.
sp.l: You lie you rogue, 'tis to the oration,

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Nay then you all lie, it is to the coblication,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: True hearted English and our valiant friends,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Do brave general i'faith.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Peace there you rogues, or I will split your chaps:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: De are countrymen, I publicly proclaim,
If any wronged discontented English,
Touched with true feeling of King hens wrongs,
Henry the ‚óèrt the lawful King of England,
Who by that tyrant Edward the usurper,
Is held a wretched prisoner in the lower,
If any man that fain would be enfranchised,
From the sad yoke of yorkish servitude,
Under which we toil like naked galley-slaves,
Know he that Thomas Nevill the lord Falconbridge:

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I and, a Falconbridge a Falconbridge:

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Peace ye clamorous rogues, on general on with poor
Oration, peace there,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Pitying King Henry's poor distressed case,
Armed with his title, and a subject's zeal,
Takes up just arms against the house of Yorks:
And do proclaim our ancient liberty:

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Liberty, liberty, liberty, general liberty.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: We do not rise like Tiler, Cade, and straw,
Blewbeard, and other of that rascal rout,
Bascly like linkers, or such muddle slaves,
for mending measures, or the price of corn,
Or for some common in the wild of Kent,
That's by some greedy cormorant enclosed:
But in the true and ancient lawful right,
Of the redoubted house of Lancaster.
Our blood is noble, by our birth a Nevill,
And by our lawful line lord Falconbridge,
Who's here that's of so dull a leaden temper,
That is not fired with a Nevil's name?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Nevill, a Nevill, a Nevill.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Our quarrel like ourself is honourable,
The law our warrant.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.l: Ay, ay, the law is on our side.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Ay, the law is in our own hands,

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Peace you rogues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: And more, a blessing by the word proposoe,
To those that aid a true anointed King,
Courage brave spirits and cry a Falconbridge,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Falconbridge, a Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: We will be masters of the mint ourselves,
And set our own stamp on the golden coin:
We'll shoe our neighing coursers with no worse
Than the purest silver that is sold in cheap.
At leaden hall we'll sell pearls by the peck,
As now the mealemen use to sell their meal:
In Westminster we'll keep a solemn court,
And build it bigger to receive our men,
Cry Falconbridge my heart's liberty,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Falconbridge and liberty, etc.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.l: Peace ye slaves, or I will smoke ye else,

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.p: Peace ye slaves, or I will chub your chaps, but indeed thou mayst well smoke them, because thy name is smoke.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.p: Why sirrah, I hope smoke the smith of Chepsted, is as good a man as Chubb the chandler of Sandwich.

sp.speaker: Spicing.
sp.l:
Peace ye rogues, what are you quarrelling? and
now list to captain spicing.
You know Cheapside there are the mercer's shops,
Where we will measure velvet by the pikes:
And silks and satins by the streets whole breadth:
We'll take the tankards from the conduit cocks,
To fill with hippocras and drink carouse.
Where chains of gold and plate shall be as plenty,
As wooden dishes in the wild of Kent:

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.p: O bravely said Ned spicing, the honestest lad that ever punde spice in a mortar, now speaks captain smoke.

sp.l: Look lads for from this hill ye may discern,
The lovely town which we are marching to,
That same is London lads ye look upon,
Range all a-row my hearts and stand at gaze,
As do the herds of dear at some strange sight:
Or as a troop of hungry travellers,
That fire their eyes upon a furmentied feast,
Look how the tower doth 'tice us to come on,
To take out Henry the sixth there prisoner,
See how s. Katherine's smokes, wipe slaves your eyes
And whet your stomachs for the good malt pies.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Why then belike I am nobody : room and avoidance, for now speaks captain Chubb:
No sooner in London will we be,
But the bakers for you, the brewers for me,
Birchin lane shall suit us, the costermonger's fruit us:
The poulters send us in soul,
And butcher's meat without control:
And ever when we sup or dine,
The vintners freely bring us in wine:
If anybody ask who shall pay,
Cut off his head and send him away.
This is captain Chubb's law whosoever say nay.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Bravely resolved, so march we forward all,
And boldly say, good luck shall us befall.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter the lord Maior, m. Shoare. M. Josseline, in their velvet coats, and gorgets, and leading staves.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This is well done, thus should good citizens,
Fashion themselves as well for war as peace:
Have ye commanded that in every street,
They hang forth lights as soon as night comes one
Say Colin Shore that was referred to you.
Shore „Äà‚óä„Äâ have my lord, besides from every hall
There is at least two hundred men in arms.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It cheers my heart to hear this readiness,
Let never rebels put true subjects down,
Come when they will, their welcome shall be such,
As they had better kept them further off.
But where is m. recorder? his advice,
Must not be wanting in these high affairs.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: About an hour ago, and somewhat more,
I left him fortifying the bridge my lord,
Which done he purposed to meet you here:

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A discreet painful gentleman he is,
And we must all of us be so inclined:
If we intend to have the city safe,
Or look for thanks, and credit with the King,
I tell ye masters, aged though I be,
I (For my part) will to no bed this night.

sp.speaker: Ioss.
sp.l: Why is it thought the bastard is so near?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How mean ye m. Josseline by near?
He neither comes from Italy nor Spain:
But out of Kent, and Essex which you know,
Are both so near, as nearer cannot be.

sp.speaker: Ioss.
sp.l: Nay, by your patience good my lord a word,
Simple though I am, yet I must confess,
A mischief further off, would, and so forth,
You know my meaning, things not seen before,
Are, and so forth, yet in good sadness,
I would that all were well, and perchance,
it may be so, what, were it not for hope,
The heart, and so forth, but to the matter,
You mean and purpose, ay, ay, am sure ye do?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Well m. Josseline, we are sure ye mean well
Although somewhat defective in your utterance.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Ay, ay, my lord mayor, I am you know,
Willing ready, and so forth, tut, tut, for me, ha, ha,
My Manston is at ham, and thence you know,
I come to help you in this needful time:
When rebels are so busy, and so forth,
What masters, age must never be despised,
You shall find me my lord, still, and so forth.

div.stage: Enter Urswick the recorder.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: My lord, now here comes m. recorder.

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: Good even my good lord mayor, the streets are chained,
The bridge well manned and every place prepared,
Shall we now go together and consult.
What else there is to be determined of?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your coming m. Recorder was the thing
We all desired, therefore let us consult,
And now what say ye, if with half our power,
We issue forth, and give the rebels fight?

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: Before they do provoke us nearer hand
There were no way to that, if all be pleased,
What's your opinion m. Josseline?

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Good sooth my l. mayor, and m. recorder,
You may take your choice, but in my conceit,
Issue if you will, or else stay if you will,
A man can never be too wary and so forth,
Yet as to issue will not be the worst,
Even so to tarry, well, you may think more on't,
But all is one, we shall be sure to fight,
And you are wise enough, to see your time, ay, ay, a god's name.

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: My lord accept his meaning better than his counsel.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ay, so we do, or else we were to blame,
What if we stop the passage of the Thames,
With such provision as we have of ships?

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: Its doubtful yet my lord, whether the rebels,
Purpose that way to seek our detriment,
Rather me seemeth they will come by land,
And either make assault at London bridge,
Or else at Algate, both which entrances,
Were good they should be strongly fortified.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Well said master recorder, you do, I I, I warrant

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: As for the other, the whole companies
Of mercers, grocers, drapers, and the rest,
Are drawn together for their best defence,
Beside the tower, a neighbour to that place,
As on the one side it will clear the river,
So on the other with their ordnance,
It may repulse and beat them from the gate,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What noise is this? provide ye suddenly:
And every man betake him to his charge.

div.stage: Enter a messenger.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Soft who is this, how now my friend what news?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: My master the lieutenant of the tower, gives ye to understand, he hath descried the army of the rebels.

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: Which may come they?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: From essexward, and therefore 'tis his mind,
You guard both Algate well, and Bishopsgate.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Saint George away, and let us all resolve,
Either to vanquish this rebellious rout,
Preserve our goods, our children and our wives,
Or seal our resolution with our lives.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Falconbridge, spicing, with his troops.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Summon the city, and command our entrance,
Which if we shall be stubbornly denied,
Our power shall rush like thunder through the walls,

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Open your gates slaves when I command ye,

Spicing beats on the gates, and then enters the lord maior
and his associates with prentices.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: What's he that beats thus at the city gates,
Commanding entrance as he were a King?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: He that will have releasement for a King:
I Thomas Nevell the lord Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Spi
sp.l: H‚óè sirrah, you, clapper, ‚óèche, bolt,
Or ‚óèe bolt you if I get in, stand you preaching with a poor?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: We have no warrant I ho. Falconbridge,
To let your armed troops into our city,
Considering you have taken up these arms,
Against our sovereign and our country's peace.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I tell thee mawr, and know he tells thee so,
That cometh armed in a King's defence,
That I crave entrance in Kings Henry's name,
In right of the true line of Lancaster,
Methinks that word spoken from a Nevil's mouth
Should like an earthquake rend your chained gates,
And tear in pieces your portcullises,
I thunder it again into you ears,
You stout and brave courageous Londoners,
In Henry's name I crave my entrance in.

sp.speaker: ‚óèr.
sp.l: Should Henry's name command thee entrance here
We should deny allegiance unto Edward,
Whose true and faithful subjects we are sworn,
And in whose presence is our sword up borne.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I tell thee traitor than thou bearest thy sword
Against thy true undoubted King.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Nay then I tell thee bastard Falconbridge,
My lord major bears his sword in his defence,
That put the sword into the arms of London,
Made the lord Malors for ever after knights,
Richard, deposed ... Henry Bolingbroke,
From whom the house of York doth claim their right.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What's he that answers us thus saucily

sp.speaker: Smo.
sp.l: Sirrah your name, that we may know ye hereafter,

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: My name is Shore, a goldsmith by my trade,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What not that Shore that hath the dainty wife,
Shore's wife, the flower of London for her beauty.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Yes rebel even the very same.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Run rascal and fetch thy wife to our general presently, or else all the gold in Cheapside cannot ransom her: wilt thou not stir when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Shore listen me, thy wise is mine that's flat,
This night in thine own house she sleeps with me,
Now Crosbie lord maior shall we enter in?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Crosbie the lord maior tells thee proud rebel no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No Crosbie shall I not: then doting lord,
I cram the name of rebel down thy throat,
There's not the poorest rascal of my camp,
But if he chance to meet thee in Cheapside
Upon thy foot-cloth, he shall make thee light,
And hold his stirrup while he mount thy horse,
Than lackey him which way he please to go,
Crosbie I'll make the citizens be glad,
To send thee and the aldermen thy brothers,
All manacled, and chained like galley slaves,
To ransom them, and to redeem the city.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Nay then proud rebel, pause and hear me speak,
There's not the poorest and meanest citizen,
That is a faithful subject to the King.
But in despite of thy rebellious rout,
Shall walk to bow, a small wand in his ‚óèd
Although thou lie encamped at Mile-end green,
And not the proudest rebel of you all,
Shall dare to touch him for his damned soul.
Come, we will pull up our portcullises,
And let me see thee enter if thou dare.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Spoken like a man, and true velvet jacket,
And we will enter or strike by the way.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter lord major, recorder, and josseline.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Where's master Recorder, and master Josseline?

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.p:
Here my lord mayor, we now have manned the
walls, and fortified such places as were needful,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why it is well, brothers and citizens,
Stick to your city as good men should do,
Think that in Richard's time even such a rebel,
Was then by Walworth the l. mayor of London,
Stabbed dead in Smithfield:
Then show yourselves as it be fits the time.
And let this find a hundreth Walworth, now,
Dare stab a rebel were he made of brass,
And prentices stick to your officers,
For you may come to be as we are now,
God and our King against an arrant rebel,
Brothers away, let us defend our walls:

sp.speaker: 1. pren
sp.l: My lord your words are able to infuse,
A double courage in a coward's breast,
Then fear not us although our chins be bare,
Our hearts are good, the trial shall be seen,
Against these rebels on this champion green.

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.l: We have no tricks nor policies of war,
But by the ancient custom of our fathers,
We'll soundly lay it on, take't off that will.
And London prentices be ruled by me,
Die ere ye lose fair London's liberty.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: How now my flatcaps, are you grown so brave?
'Tis but your words, when matters come to propose
You'll scud as 'twere a company of sheep,
My counsel therefore is to keep your shops,
What lack you, better will beseem your mouths,
Than terms of war, in sooth you are too young:

sp.speaker: Prostitute
sp.l: Sirrah go too, you shall not find it so,
Flatcaps thou callest us, we scorn not the name,
And shortly by the virtue of our swords,
We'll make your cap so sit unto your crown,
As sconce and cap and all kiss the ground.

sp.speaker: 2. Prostitute
sp.l: You are those desperate idle swaggering mates,
That haunt the suburbs in the time of peace,
and raise up ale-house braules in the street,
And when the rumor of the war begins,
You hide your heads, and are not to be found,
Thou termest it better that we keep our shops,
It's good indeed we should have such a care,
But yet for all our keeping now and then,
Your pelfring fingers break into our locks,
Until at Tyburn you acquit the fault:
Go to, albeit by custom we are mild,
As those that do profess civility,
Yet being moved, a nest of angry hornets
Shall not be more offensive then we will,
We'll fly about your ears and sting your hearts.

sp.speaker: Ioss.
sp.l: He tells you truth my friends, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Who can endure to be so vrauce by boys?

sp.speaker: 1. Prostitute
sp.l: Nay scorn us not that we are prentices,
The chronicles of England can report,
What memorable actions we have done,
To which this day's achievement shall be knit,
To make the volume larger than it is.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now of mine honour, ye do cheer my heart
Brave English offsprings, valiantly resolved.

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.l: My lord return you back, let us alone,
You are our masters, give us leave to work,
And if we do not vanquish them in fight,
Let us go supperless to bed at night.

div.stage: Exeunt all but spicing, smoke, and their crew.

sp.speaker: Spi. Sm.
sp.p: Get thee up on the top of s. Buttolph's steeple, and make a proclamation.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.l: What a plague should I proclaim there?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: That the hells be rung backward,
And cutting of throats be cried havoc,
No more calling of lantern and candlelight,
That maidenheads be valued at just nothing:
And sack be sold by the salad.
That no piddling slave stand to pick a lock, but slash me off the hinges, as one would slit up a cow's paunch.

sp.speaker: Spicing.
sp.p: Let no man have less than a warehouse to his wardrobe: cry a fig for a sergeant, and walk by the counter like a lord, pluck out the clapper of bow bell, and hang up all the sextons in the city.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.p: rantam-scantam , rogues follow your leader, cavalero spicing the maddest slave that ere pounded spice in a mortar.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Take me an usurer by the greasy pouch, and shake out his crowns, as a hungry dog would shake a haggis, bar foul play rogues, and live by honest filching and stealing, he that hath a true finger, let him forfeit his face to the frying-pan.
Follow your leader rogues, follow your leader.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.l: Assault, assault, and cry a Falconbridge.

div.stage: Josseline on the walls cries to them.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Sirrah spicing, if spicing be thy name, we are here for matters and causes as it might ‚óème for the King, therefore it were good, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Open the gates, or if we be the picklocks, ye rogues we'll play the mastiff dogs amongst you: if I worry not a thousand of you with my teeth, let me be hanged in a packthread, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Fond fellow, justice is to be used, I marry is it, and law in some sort as it were is to be followed, o God forbid else, this our magistrate hath power as might seem, and so forth, for duty is to be observed, and officers must be obeyed, in sort and calling, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: We'll talk more anon, good m. and so forth.

div.stage: Here is a very fierce assault on all sides, wherein the prentices do great service.
Enter Falconbridge angry with his men.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why this it is to trust to these base rogues.
This dirty scum of rascal pesantry:
this heartless rout of base rascality;
A plague upon you all, you cowardly rogues;
You cravand curs, you say muddy clowns,
Whose courage but consists in multitude,
Like sheep and neat that follow one another,
Which if one run away, all follow after:
This hedge-bred rascal, this filthy fry of ditches,
A vengeance take you all, this 'tis to lead you,
Now do you cry and shriek at every shock,
A hot consuming mischief follow you.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: 'Swounds scale rogues, scale, a Falconbridge, a Falconbridge.

div.stage: Enter lord Maior and histraine.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Set open the gates, nay then we'll sally out,
It never shall be said when I was mayor,
The Londoners were shut up in the city,
Then cry King Edward, and let's us issue out.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Now if ye be true hearted Englishmen,
The gates set open and the portcullis up:
Let's Pel mell in, to stop their passage out,
He that first enters, be possessed of cheap,
I give him it freely, and the chiefest wench.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: That he can find, let that lie in the bargain.

div.stage: Exeunt.
The lord Maior and the citizens having valiantly repulsed the rebels from the city: enters Falconbridge and spicing and their train wounded and dismayed.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Hearest thou general, there's hot drinking at the mouth of Bishopsgate, for our soldiers are all mouth, they lie like rascals with their brains beaten out, therefore since we are all like to feed hogs in Houndsditch, let us retire our troops, and save our maimed men, or if we issue further, we are put to the sword every mother's son of us.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Art thou that villain in whose damned mouth,
Was never heard of any word but wounds?
Whose recreant limbs are notched with gaping scars,
Thicker than any carking craft-mans score,
Whose very scalp is scratched and crazed and broken,
Like an old mazzer beaten on the stones,
And standest thou now to save our maimed men?
A plague upon thee coward.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Why how now base Thomas? 'swounds, wert thou a base vial, thou art but a rascal and a rebel as I am, hearest thou, if I do not turn true subject and leave thee, let me be worried with dogs, 'swounds dost thou impeach my manhood? Tom Nevill thou hadst as good to have damned thyself as uttered such a word, flatly I forsake thee, and all that love Ned spicing follow me.

div.stage: Here the rest offer to follow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Come come ye testy soul, thou seest me grieved,
Yet canst not bear with mine infirmity,
Thou knowest I hold thee for as tall a man
As any lives or breathes our English air,
I know there lives not a more fiery spirit,
A more resolve dalliant, a plague upon it,
Thou knowest I love thee, yet if a word escape
My lips in anger, how tasty than thou art?
I had rather all men left me then thyself,
Thou art my soul, thou art my genius:
I cannot live without thee not an hour,
Thus must I still be forced against my will,
To soothe this dirty slave, this cowardly rascal.
Come, come be friends, ye tasty firebrand,
We must retire there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Nay Tom, if thou wilt have me mount on the walls,
And cast myself down headlong on their pikes,
He do it, but to impeach my valour,
Had any man but thou spoke half so much,
I would have spilled his heart, still be ware
My valour, such words go hardly down,
Well, I am friends, thou thoughtest not as thou spak'st.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No on my soul, thou thinkest not that I did,
Sound a retreat there I command ye straight,
But whither shall we retire

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: To Mile-end green, there's no fitter place.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Then let us back retire to Mile-end green,
And there expect fresh succour from our friends,
With such supply as shall ere long assure
The city is our own, march on, away.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter the l. mayor with his train and prentices.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.l: Ye have bestead ye like good citizens,
And she wne yourselves true subjects to your King,
You worthily prentice bestirred yourselves,
That it did there my heart to see your valour,
The rebels are retired to Mileend green,

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: Where so we may not suffer them to rest.
But issue forth upon them with fresh force.

sp.speaker: Los.
sp.p: My l. mayor, diligence doth well, and so forth. Matters must be looked into as they ought, indeed should they, when things are well done, they are, and so forth, for causes and things must indeed be looked into.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Well sir, we very well conceive your meaning,
And you have showned yourself a worthy gentleman:
See that our walls be kept with courts of guard,
And well defended against the enemy,
For we will now withdraw us to Guildhall ,
To take advice what further must be done.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter master Shoare and Janc his wife.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Be not afraid (Sweet heart) the worst is past,
God have the praise, the victory is ours,
We have prevailed, the rebels are repulsed,
And every street of London soundeth joy,
Canst thou then (Gentle Janc) be sad alone?

sp.speaker: Janc.
sp.l: I am not sad now you are here with me,
my toy, my hope, my comfort, and my love,
My dear, dear husband, kindest Mathew shore,
But when these arms the circles of my soul,
Were in the fight so forward as I heard,
How could I choose, sweet heart, but be afraid?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Why dost thou tremble now, when peril's past

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I think upon the horror of the tune,
But tell me why you fought so desperately?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: First to maintain King Edward's royalty,
Next to defend the city's liberty,
But chiefly ta'en to keep thee from the foil,
Of him that to my face did how thy spoil,
Had he prevailed, where then had been our lives,
Dishonoured our daughters, ravished our fair wives,
Possessed our goods, and set our servants free,
Yet all this nothing to the loss of thee.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Of me sweet heart? why how should I be lost?
Were I by thousand storms of fortune tossed?
And should endure the poorest wretched life,
Yet Jane will be thy honest loyal wife,
The greatest prince the sun did ever see,
Shall never make me prove untrue to thee:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I fear not fair means, but a rebel's force,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: These hands shall make this body a dead corpse,
Ere force or flattery shall mine honour stain,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: True fame survives, when death the flesh hath slain.

div.stage: Enter an officer from the lord Maior.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: God save ye master shore, and mistress by your leave,
Sir my l. maior sends for ye by major,
And prates your speedy presence at Guildhall ,
There's news the rebels have made head again,
And have ensconced themselves upon Mile-end,
And presently our armed men must out,
You being captain of two companies
In honour of your valour and your skill,
must lead the vaward, God and right stand with ye.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Friend tell my lord I'll wait upon him straight.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Friend tell my lord he does my husband wrong,
To set him foremost in the danger still,
Ye shall not go if I may have my will,

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Peace wife, no more, friend I will follow ye,

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'faith ye shall not, prithee do not go.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Not go sweet heart? that were a coward's trick,
A traitor's part to shrink when others fight,
Envy shall never say that Mathew Shore
The goldsmith stayed, when other men went out,
To meet his Kings and country's enemy,
No Jane 'gainst all the rebels on Mile-end,
I dare alone K. Edward's right defend.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If you be slain, what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Kite well my wench, I now will marry thee,
I leave thee worth at least five thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Marry again. that word my heart doth wound,
I'll never marry, nor I will not live,
If thou be killed, let me go with thee Mat.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis idle talk good Jane, no more of that,
Go to my lady majoress and the rest,
As you are still companion with the best,
With them be merry, and pray for our good speed,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: To part from thee my very heart doth bleed.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Falconbridge with his troops marching, as being at Mile-end.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yet stand we in the sight of upreared Troy,
And suck the air she draws: our every breath
Flies from our nostrils warm unto the walls,
We beard her bristling spires, her battled towers,
And proudly stand and gaze her in the face,
Look on me, and I doubt not ye imagine,
My worth as great as any one of yours,
my fortunes, would I basely fawn on Edward,
To be as fair as any man's in England,
But he that keeps your sovereign in the tower,
Hath seized my land, and robbed me of my right:
I am a gentleman as well as he,
What he hath got, he holds by tyranny,
Now if you faint, or cowardly should fly,
There is no hope for any one to live,
We hear the Londoners will leave the city,
And bid us battle here on mile-end green,
Whom if we vanquish, than we take the town,
And ride in triumph thorough cheap to Paul's,
The mint is ours, cheap, Lombard street our own
The meanest soldier wealthier than a King.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: March fair ye rogues, all Kings or capknitters: dost thou hear Tom Falconbridge? I pray thee grant me one boon I shall ask thee.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What is it Ned: it's hard I should deny thee.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Why that when we have won the cry, as we cannot choose but win it, that I may have the knighting of all these rogues and rascals.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: What then? Zounds I scorn your scurvy way mouthed, what then? now a poor take me it I fight a blow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why this is fine, go to, knight whom thou wilt:

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Who, I knight any of them? I'll see them hanged first for a company of tattered ragged rascals, if I were a King, I would not knight one of them?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: What not me cavalero Chubb?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Yes, I care not if I knight thee: and yet I'll see thee hanged ere I'll honour thee so much: I care not so much for the matter, but I would not be denied my humour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why what a perverse fellow art thou Ned?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Ho my fine Tom, my brave Falconbridge, my mad Greek, my lusty Nevill: thou art a King, a Cesar, a plague on thee, I love thee not, and yet I'll die with thee.

div.stage: Enter the lord Maior, recorder, Josseline, Shoare, and their soldiers marching.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.l: See how rebellion can exalt itself,
Pruning the feathers of sick discipline.

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: They think they can outlook our truer looks,

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Mark but the scornful eye of Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I rather think 'tis fear upon his cheek,
Deciphers pale disturbance in his heart.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Our coming forth hath, well, I say no more,
But shall we take occasion, and so forth,
Rebellion should have no respite, o my lord,
The time hath bene, but all is one for that.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: How like a troop of rank o'erridden jades,
You hu‚óèse bearded citizens appear?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Nay, rather so many men in the moon,
And every one a frozen bush in his mouth.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: The so‚óè and twenty wards? now fair befall them,
Would any one have thought before this hour,
There had been such increase of muddy slaves?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Peace soldiers, they are resolute you see,
And not to sta‚óè us, nor favour them,
Such haughty sto‚óèhs seldom have been seen,
Embodied in the breasts of citizens,
How sternly in their own peculiar strength,
Without the assistance of their lingering King,
Did they of late repulse us from their walls?
And now again how expeditiously,
And unexpected they have met us here?
Were we more deadly incensed than we are,
I would not but commend their chivalry.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Captain, shall we go challenge them to fight?
'Sblood we burn daylight, they'll think anon,
We are afraid to see their glittering swords.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tell them they come in steed of pudding pies,
And Stratford cakes to makes a banquet here.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Soft give me leave, I will devise with words,
to weaken and abash their fortitude,

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: The bastard offers to come forth my lord.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am the man intend to answer him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Crosbie.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Traitor.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Traitor? zounds down with him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Be patient, give me leave I say to speak,
I doubt not but the traitor's name shall rest
With those that keeps their lawful K. in bonds:
Mean time ye men of London once again,
Behold my warlike colours are displayed,
Which I have vowed shall never be wrapped up,
Until your lofty buildings kiss our feet,
Unless you grant me passage through your streets.

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: Passage, sayest thou? that must be o'er our breasts,
If any passage thou art like to have.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why then upon your bodies will I tread,
And wade through standing pools of your lost blood.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: We know thy threats, and reckon them as wind,
Not of sufficient power to shake a reed.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: But we shook your gates not long ago,
And made your walls to shake like Irish bogs.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.p: Ay, and so terrified ye, that not one of ye ‚óèrst come to fetch a pint of sack at the mouth at Bishopsgate, no not for your lines.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: I but you know what followed, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Etcetera? are you there? methinks the sight of the dun bull, the Nevels honoured crest, should make you leave your broken sentences, and quite forget ever to speak at all.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Nay then look thou upon our city's arms.
Wherein is a bloody dagger, that is it,
Where with a rebel like to Falconbridge,
Had his desert, meet for his treachery,
Can you behold that, and not quake for fear?

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: Since when, it is successfully decreed,
traitors with us shall never better speed.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Captain and fellow soldiers talk no more,
But draw your meaning forth in down right blows.

sp.speaker: Falcon.
sp.l: Sound then alarum.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: Do the like for us, and where the right is, there attend success.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Stay and be better advised, why countrymen,
What is this Falconbridge you follow so?
I could instruct you, but you know my mind.
And Falconbridge what are these rusticalles,
Thou shouldst repose such confidence in glass,
Shall I inform thee? no, thou art wise enough,
Edward of York delays the time you say,
Therefore he will not come, imagine so,
The city's weak, hold that opinion still,
And your pretence King Henry's liberty.
True, but as how? shall I declare you? no.
What then? you'll fight, a god's name take your choice,
I can no more but give you mine advice.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Away with this parentheses of words,
Crosbie courage thy men, and on this green,
Whose cause is right, let it be quickly seen.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.l: I am as ready as thou canst desire,
On then a god's name.

div.stage: They fight, the rebels drive them back: then enter Falconbridge and spicing.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: This was well fought, now spicing list to me.
The citizens thus having given us ground,
And therefore somewhat daunted, take a band
Of Essex soldiers, and with all the speed
Thou possibly canst make, withdraw thyself,
And get between the city gates and them.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: O brave Tom Nevill, gallant Falconbridge,
Aim at thy intended policy,
this is thy meaning, while thou art employed,
And holdest them battle here on Mile-end green,
I must provide as harbinger before,
There be not only clear and open passage,
But the best merchant's houses to receive
Us and our retinue, I am proud of that,
And will not sleep upon thy just command.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Away than I will follow as I may,
And doubt not but that ours will be the day.

div.stage: After some excursions, enter lord Maior and master Shoare.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: We have recovered what before we lost,
And heaven stands with the justice of our cause,
But this I noted in the fight even now,
That part of this rebellious crew is sent,
By what direction, or for what intent,
I cannot guess, but may suspect the worst,
And as it seems, they compass it about,
To hem us in, or get the gate of us,
And therefore cousin Shore, as I repose
Trust in thy valour and thy loyalty,
Draw forth thr√©e hundred bowmen, and some pikes,
And presently encounter their assault.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I have your meaning, and effect my lord,
I trust shall disappoint them of their hope.

div.stage: After an alarum, enter spicing with a drum and certain soldiers.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Come on my hearts, we will be Kings tonight ,
Carouse in gold, and sleep with merchant's wives,
While their poor husbands lose their lives abroad,
We are now quite behind our enemies' backs,
And there's no let or hindrance in the way,
But we may take possession of the town,
Ah you mad rogues, this is the wished hour,
Follow your leader, and be resolute.

div.stage: As he marcheth, thinking to enter, Shoare and his soldier's issue forth and repulse him, after excursions, wherein the rebels are dispersed. Enter mayor, Reco. Shoa. Josseline, and a messenger talking with the mayor.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ay, my good friend, so certify his grace,
The rebels are dispersed all and fled,
And now his highness meets with victory.
Marshal your sclues, and keep in good array:
To add more glory to this victory:
The King in person cometh to this place,
How great an honour have you gained today?
And how much is this city famed for ever,
That twice without the help, either of King,
Or any, but of God, and our own selves,
We have prevailed against our countries foes?
Thanks to his majesty assisted us,
Who always helps true subjects in their need.

div.stage: The trumpets sound, then enters King Edward, L. how. Sellenger and the train.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where is my lord maior?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Here dread sovereign.
I hold no lordship nor no dignity,
In presence of my gracious lord the King,
But all I humble at your highness' feet,
With the most happy conquest of proud rebels,
Dispersed and fled, that now remains no doubt,
Of ever making head to vex us more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have not ta'en the bastard Falconbridge:
Or is he slain?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Neither my gracious lord.
Although we laboured to our uttermost,
Yet all our care came over short,
For apprehending him or spicing either
But some are taken, others on proffered grace
yielded themselves, and at your mercy stand.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thanks good l. maior, you may condemn us
Of too much slackness in such urgent need:
But we assure you on our royal word,
So soon as we had gathered us a power,
We dallied not, but mane all haste we could,
What order have ye ta'en for Falconbridge,
And his confederates in this rebellion?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Under your leave my liege, we have proclaimed
Who bringeth Falconbridge alive or dead,
Shall be requited with a thousand marks,
As much for spicing, others of less worth
At easier rates are set.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Well have ye done,
And we will see it paid from our exchequer.
Now leave we this and come to you,
That have so well deserved in these affairs,
Affairs, I mean of so main consequence.
Kneel down and all of you receive in field,
The honour you have merited in field.
sp.stage: There he draws his sword and knights them.
sp.l: Arise sir John Crosbie, L. mayor of London and knight.
Arise up sir Ralph Josseline knight.
Arise sir Thomas Urswick our recorder of London, and knight.
Now tell me which is m. Shore.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This same my lord,
And hand to hand he fought with Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Shore kneel thou down.
What call ye else his name?

sp.speaker: Recorder
sp.l: His name is Mathew Shore my lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Shore, why kneelest thou not, and at thy soueraignes hand receive thy right?

sp.speaker: Shoare.
sp.l: Pardon me gracious lord,
I do not stand contemptuous or despising
Such royal favour of my sovereign,
but to acknowledge mine unworthiness:
Far be it from the thought of Mathew Shore,
That he should be advanced with aldermen,
With our l. mayor, and our right grave recorder.
If any thing hath been performed by me,
That may deserve your highness meanest respect,
I have enough, and I desire no more.
Then let me crave that I may have no more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well, be it as thou wilt, some other way
We will devise to quittance thy deserts,
And not to fail therein upon my word.
Now let me tell ye all my friends at once,
Your King is married, since you saw him last,
And haste to help you in this needful time,
Made me on sudden to forsake my bride.
But seeing all things are fallen out so well,
And there remains no further doubt of ill,
Let me entreat you would go boot yourselves,
And bring your King a little on his way.
How say you my lord, shall it be so?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now God forbid but that my lord the King
Should always have his subjects at command.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Forbid quotha? I in good sadness, your majesty shall find us always ready, and so forth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why then set forward gentlemen,
And come l. maior, I must confer with you.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Falconbridge and spicing with their weapons in their hands.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Art thou the man whose victories drawn at sea,
Filled every heart with terror of thy name?
Art thou that Nevill whom we took thee for?
Thou art a louse, thou bastard Falconbridge?
Thou baser than a bastard, in whose birth
The very dregs of servitude appears,
Why tell me, liver of some rotten sheep,
after by thy allurements we are brought,
To undertake this course, after thy promises
Of many golden mountains to ensue,
Is this the greatest comfort thou canst glu‚óè?
Hast thou ensnared our heedless feet with death,
And brought us to the gibbet of defame,
And now dost bid us shift and save ourselves?
No craven were I sure I should be ta'en,
I would not stir my feet, until this hand
Had venged me on thee for misguiding us.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Opprobrious villain, stable excrement,
That never dreamest of other manhood yet,
But how to jerk a horse, until my words
Ensued into thee resolutions sire.
Control'st thou me for that wherein thyself,
Art only the occasion of mishap?
Hadst thou and they stood to it as well as I,
The day had been our own, and London now,
That laughs in triumph, should have wept in tears,
But being backed by such faint hearted slaves
No marvel if the lion go to wrack,
As though it were not incident to Kings,
Sometime to take repulse, mine is no more:
Nor is not for that muddy brain of thine
To tutor me how to digest my loss,
Then fly with those that are already fled,
Or stay behind, and hang all but the head.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: O prejudice to spicings conquering name,
Whose valour even the hacks this sword has made
Upon the flint, and iron bars at Aldgate:
Like mouths will publish whiles the city stands
That I shrunk backe‚óè that I was never seen
To show my manly spleen, but with a whip.
I tell thee Falconbridge the least of these,
Do challenge blood before they be appeased,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Away ye scoundrel, tempt not my resolve,
the courage that survives in Falconbridge,
Scorns the encounter of so base a drudge.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: By the pure temper of this sword of mine,
By this true flesh and blood that gripes the same,
And by the honour I did win of late,
Against those frosty bearded citizens,
It shall be tried before we do depart,
Whether accuseth other wrongfully,
Or which of us two is the better man.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I shall but quit the hangman of a labour,
Yet rather than to be upbraided thus,
The eagle once will stoop to feed on carrion.

div.stage: They fight, enter chub.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Hold if ye be men, if not, hold as ye are: rebels and strong thieves: I bring you news of a proclamation, the King hath promised that whosoever can bring the head of Falconbridge, or spicing, shall have for his labour a thousand crowns, what mean you then to swagger? save yourselves.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: This proclamation comes in happy time,
I'll vanquish Falconbridge, and with this sword
Cut off his head, and bear it to the King,
So not alone shall I be pardoned,
But have the thousand crowns is promised.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: This rascal was ordained to save my life,
For now when I have overthrown the wretch,
Even with his head I'll yield me to the King,
His princely word is past to pardon me,
And though I were the chief in this rebellion,
Yet this will be a means to make my peace.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O that I knew how to betray them both.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: How sayest thou spi. wilt thou yield thyself?
For I have vowed either alive or dead
To bring thee to King Edward?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: And I have vowed the like by thee.
How will these two bad contraries agree?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: And I the same by both of you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Come sir, I'll quickly c‚óèd you of that care.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: And what thou 'lottest me, shall be thy share.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Here comes a miller, help to part the fray,
These are the rebels Falconbridge and spicing,
The worst of them is worth a thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Marry and such a booty should I have,
Submit, submit, it is in vain to strive,

div.stage: Exit Fal.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Why what art thou:

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: One that will hamper yond,
But what's the other that is fled away?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: O miller, that was Falconbridge,
And this is spicing his companion.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: I tell thee miller thou hast been the means,
To hinder the most charitable deed,
Whatever honest christian undertook.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Thou canst bear nigh witness I had fane
That most notorious rebel but for him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But I have taken thee, and the world knows,
That spicing is as bad as who is best.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Why thou mistakst, I am a true subject.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Miller he lies, be sure to hold him fast.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Dost thou accuse me? apprehend him too,
For he's as guilty as any of us.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Come you shall both together answer it,
Before my lord mayor, and here he comes.

div.stage: Enter lord Maior, Josseline, and other attendants.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sir Ralph Josseline, have you ever seen a prince more affable than Edward is? what merry talk he had upon the way.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Doubtless my lord he'll prove a royal King.
But how now what are these?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: God save your honour,
Here I present unto you my lord mayor,
A pair of rebels, whom I did espy
As I was busy grinding at my mill,
And taking them for vagrant idle knaves,
That had beset some trueman from his house,
I came to keep the peace, but afterwards,
Found that it was the bastard Falconbridge,
And this his mate together by the ears,
The one, for all that I could do, escaped,
The other standeth at your mercy here.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It is the rebel spicing.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: It is indeed?
I see you are not blind, you know me then.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Well miller, thou hast done a subject's part,
And worthily deservest that recompense
Is publicly proclaimed by the King,
But what's this other? I have seen his face,
And as I take it, he is one of them.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I must confess, I took them both together,
‚óèee aided me to apprehend the rest.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.p: 'A tells you true my lord, I am Chubb the chandler, and I curse the time that ever I saw their faces, for if they had not been, I had lived an honest man in mine own country, and never come to this,

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Out rogue, dost thou recant for fear of death?
I major, I am he that sought to cut your throat,
And since I have miscarried in the fact,
I'll ne'er deny it, do the worst you can.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Bring him a way, he shall have martial law, and at the next tree we do come unto,
Be hanged to rid the world of such a wretch.
Miller thy duty is a thousand marks,
Which must be shared betwixt thee and this poor fellow, that did reveal him. And sirrah, your life is saved on this condition, that you hang up spicing, how sayest thou, wilt thou do it?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Will I do it? what a question is that?
I would hang him if he were my father to save mine own life.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Then when ye have done it, come home to my house, and there ye truly shall have your reward.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Well sirrah, than thou must be my hangman?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: I by my troth sir, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Well, commend me to little Pim, and pray her to redeem my pande hose, they lie at the blue boar for eleven pence, and if my hostess will have the other odd penny, tell her she is a damned bawd, and there is no truth in her score.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.p: Take no thought sir for your panned hose, they are lousy, and not worth the redeeming.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: There is a constable sticks in my mind, he got my sword from me, that night I should have killed black Ralph, if I had ‚óèude, I would have been meet with him.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Ay sir, but here's a thing shall take an order for that.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Commend me to black luce, bouncing Bess, and lusty Kate, and the other pretty morsels of man's flesh. Farewell pink and pinnace, Flibote, and carvel, Turnbull, and spittle, I die like a man.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: O captain spicing, thy vain enticing, brought me from my trade,
From good candles making, to this pains taking, a rebel to be made,
Therefore Ned Spicing, to quit thy enticing, this must be thy hope,
By one of thy fellows, to be led to the gallows, to end in a rope.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Hobs the tanner of Tamworth:

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
Dudgeon, dost thou he are, look well to Brocke my mare, drive Dunne and her fair and softly down the hill, and take heed the thorns tear not the horns of my cow hides, as thou goest near the hedges: ha what sayest thou knave? is the bulls hide down? why lay it up again, what rare I? He meet thee at the style, and help to set all straight. And yet God help, it's a crooked world, and an unthrifty, for some that have ne'er a shoe, had rather go barefoot, then buy clout-leather to mend the old, when they can buy no new, for they have time enough to mend all, they sit so long between the cup and the wall, well God amend them, God amend them. Let me see by my executor here, my leather pouch,
what I have taken, what I have spent, what I have gained. what I have lost, and what I have laid cut: my taking is more than my spending, for here's store left. I have spent but a groat, a penny for my two jades, a penny to the poor, a penny pot of ale, and a penny cake for my man and me, a dicker of cowhides cost me.
sp.stage: Here enter the Queen and Duchess with their riding rods, unpinning their masks, Hobs goes forward.
sp.p: Snails who comes here? mistress Ferries, or mistress what call ye her? Put up John Hobs, money tempts beauty.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Well met good fellow, sawest thou not the hart?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: My heart? God bless me from seeing my heart.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thy heart? the d√©ereman, we demand the decree.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Do you demand what's dear? marry corn and cow hides, mass a good smug lass, well like my daughter Nell, I had rather than a bend of leather she and I might smutch together.

sp.speaker: Duchess.
sp.l: Camest thou not down the wood?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Yes mistress that I did.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And sawest thou not the dear embossed?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: By my hood ye make me laugh, what the dickens is it love that makes ye prate to me so fondly, by my father's soul I would I had iobd faces with you.

sp.speaker: Huntsman
sp.p: Why how now Hobs, so saucy with the Duchess and the Queen?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Much Queen I trow, these be but women, and one of them is like my wench, I would she had her rags, I would give a load of hair and horns, and a fat of leather, to match her to some justice, by the meghollie.

sp.speaker: 2. Huntsman
sp.l: Be silent tanner, and ask pardon of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: And ye be the Queen, I cry ye mercy good mistress Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No fault my friend, madam let's take our bows,
And in the standing seek to get a shoot.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Come bend our bows, and bring the herd of deer.

div.stage: Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: God send ye good standing, and good striking, and fat flesh, see if all gentle women be not alike when their black face be on, I took the Queen, as I am true tanner, for mistress Ferris.

div.stage: Enter Sellenger and Howard in Greene.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Soft, who comes here, more knaves yet?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Ho good fellow, sawst thou not the King?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: No good fellow, I saw no King, which King dost thou ask for.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: Why King Edward, what King is there else?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: There's another King and ye could hit on him, one Harry, one Harry, and by our lady they say, he's the honester man of the two.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sirrah beware you speak not treason.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: What if I do?

sp.speaker: Sell.
sp.l: Then thou'lt be hanged.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: A dog's death, I'll not meddle with it, for by my troth I know not when I speak treason, when I do not, there's such halting betwixt two Kings, that a man cannot go upright, but he shall offend tone of them, I would God had them both for me.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: Well, thou sawest not the King?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No, is he in the country?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: ‚óèes hunting here at Drayton Basset.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: The devil he is, God bless his mastership: I saw a woman here that they said was the Queen, she's as like my daughter, but my daughter is the fairer, as ever I see.

sp.speaker: Sell.
sp.l: Fare well fellow, speak well of the King,

div.stage: Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: God make him an honest man, I hope that's well spoken, for byth' mouse foot, some give him hard words, whether be serves 'em or not, let him look to that, I'll meddle of my cow hide, and let the world slide.

The devil in a dung cart, how these roisters swarm in the country now the King is so near? God liver me from this, for this looks like a cheese, but a man cannot tell amongst
these courtnoles whose true.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Holla my friend, good fellow pray thee stay.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No such matter, I have more haste of my way.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: If thou be a good fellow, let me borrow a word.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: My purse thou meanest, I am no good fellow, and I pray God thou beest not one.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Why? dost thou not love a good fellow?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: No, good fellows be thieves.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Dost thou think I am one?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Thought is free, and thou art not my ghostly father.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: I mean thee no harm.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Who knows that but thyself? I pray God he spy not my purse.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: On my troth I mean she none.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Upon thy oath I'll stay: now, what sayest thou to me? Speak quickly, for my company stays for me beneath at the next style.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: The King is hunting hereabouts, didst thou see his majesty?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: His majesty, what's that? his horse, or his mare?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Tush, I mean his grace.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Grace quotha? pray God he have any: which King dost thou choir for?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: Why for King Edward, knowest thou any more Kings than one?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I know not so many, for I tell thee I know none, marry I hear of King Edward.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Didst thou see his highness?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: By my holidame, that's the best term thou gav'st him yet, he's high enough, but he has put poor King Harry low enough.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: How low hath he put him?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot tell, but he has put him down, for he has got the crown, much good do't him with it.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Amen, I like thy talk so well, I would I knew thy name.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Dost thou not know me?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Then thou knowest nobody : didst never hear of John Hobs the tanner of Tamworth ?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Not till now I promise thee, but now I like thee well.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: So do not I thee, I fear thou art some out-rider, that lives by taking of purses here on Basset's heath, but I fear thee not, for I have wared all my money in cowhides, at colesill market, and my man and my mare are hard by at the hill foot.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: ‚óès that thy grey mare that's tide at the style with the h‚óèes on her back ':

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: That's Brocke my mare, and there's Dun my nag, and Dadgeon my man.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: There's neither man nor horse, but only one mare.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: God's bl‚óèw bodkin, has the knave served me so? farewell, I may lose his, horns, and mare and all, by prating with thee.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: Tarry man, tarry, they'll sooner take my gelding than thy gray mare, for I ‚óèue tide mine by her.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: That will I see afore I'll take your word.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: I'll bear thee company.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I had as lief go alone:

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter the two huntsmen again with the bows.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunts.
sp.l: ‚óèow on my troth the Queen shoots passing well.

sp.speaker: 2. Hunts.
sp.l: So did the Duchess when she was as young.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunts.
sp.l: Age s‚óès the hand, and shoots both wide and short:

sp.speaker: 2. Hunts.
sp.l: What have they given us?

sp.speaker: 1. Hunts.
sp.l: S‚óère rose nobles lust:

sp.speaker: 2. Hunts.
sp.l: The Queen gave four.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunts.
sp.l: True, and the Duchess twain.

sp.speaker: 2. Hunts.
sp.l: O were we ever so paid for our pain.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunts.
sp.p: ‚óèut, had the King come, as they said he would, he would have rained upon us showers of gold.

sp.speaker: 2 Hunts.
sp.p: Why he is hunting somewhere here about, let's first go drink, and then go seek him out.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter King Edward again, and hobs.

sp.speaker: K. Ed
sp.p: How saist thou tanner, wilt thou take my courser for thy mare?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Courser callst thou him? so ill might I fare, thy skittish jade will never abide, to carry my leather, my horns nor hide. But if I were so mad to scorce, what boot wouldst thou give nice?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: May boot, that's boot worthy, I look for boot of thee.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Ha, ha, a merry jig, why man, Brocke my mare knows ha and ree, and will stand when I cry ho, and let me get up and down, and make water when I do.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: I'll give thee a noble if I like her pace, lay thy cowhides in my saddle, and let's jog towards Drayton.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: It's out of my way, but I begin to like thee well.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thou wilt like me better before we do part,
I pray thee tell me, what say they of the King?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Of the Kings thou meanest, art thou no blab if I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: If the King know't not now, he shall never know it for me.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Mass they say King harry's a very adultery man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A devout man, and what's King Edward?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: He's a frank franion, a merry companion, and loves a wench well, they say he has married a poor widow because shees fair.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dol‚óè thou like him the worse for that?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: No by my feckens, but the better, for though I be a plain tanner, I love a fair lass myself.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Prithee tell me, how love they King Edward?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Faith as poor folks love holidays, glad to have them now and then, but to have them come too often, will undo them, so to see the King now and then 'tis comfort, but every day would beggar us, and I may to thee, we fear we shall be troubled to lend him no money, for we doubt he's but needy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wouldst thou lend him no money if he should need?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: By my halidom yes, he shall have half my store, and I'll sell sole leather to help him to more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Faith whether lovest thou better Harry or Edward.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Nay, that's co√∫nsel, and two may keep it, if one be a way.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Shall I say my conscience? I think Harry is the true King.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Art advised of that? Harry's of the old house of Lancashire, and that progenity do I love.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And thou dost not hate the house of York?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why no, for I am just a kin to Sutton Windmill, I can grind which way soe'er the wind blow, if it be Harry I can say well fare Lancaster, if it be Edward I can sing, York, York for my monse.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Thou art of my mind, but I say harrie's the lawful King, Edward is but an usurper, and a fool and a coward.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Nay there thou liest, he has wit enough, and courage enough, do thou not speak treason?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay, but I know to whom I speak it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Dost thou? well if I were constable, I should be forsworn if I set thee not in the stocks for it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well let it go no further, for I did serve King Harry and I love him best, though now I serve King Edward.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Thou art the arranter knave to speak ill of thy master, but sirrah what's thy name, what office hast thou? and what will the King do for thee?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My name is Ned, I am the King's butler, and he will do more for me, then for any noble man in the court.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: The devil he will, he's the more fool, and so I'll tell him, if ere I see him, and I would I might see him in my poor house at Tamworth.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Go with me to the court and I'll bring thee to the King, and what suit soe'er thou have to him, the warrant thee to speed

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I ha' nothing to do at court, I'll home with my cowhides, and if the King will come to me he shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Hast thou no suit touching thy trade, to transport hides or sell leather only in a certain circuit, or about bark, or such like, to have letters patents?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
By the mass and the matins I like not those patents, sirrah they that have them, do as the priests did in old time, buy and sell the sins of the people, so they make the King believe they mend what's amiss, and for money they
make the thing worse than it is, there's another thing in too, the more is the pity?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What pity John Hobs? I prithee say all.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Faith 'tis pity that one subica should have in his hand that might do good to many through the land.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Satest thou me so tanner well let's cast lots whether thou shalt go with me to Drayton, or I go home with thee to Tamworth.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Lot me no lotting, I'll not go with thee, if thou wilt go with me, cause thou'rt my liege's man (And yet I think be has many honester) thou shalt be welcome to John Hobs, thou shalt be welcome to ‚óèese and bacon, and perhaps a bag-pudding, and my daughter Nell shall pop a posset upon thee when thou ghost to bed.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Here's my hand, I'll but go and see the King served, and I'll be at home as soon as thyself.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Dost thou hear me Ned? if I shall be thy host,
Make haste thou art best, for fear thou kiss the ‚óèost.

div.stage: Exit, Hobs.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Farewell John Hobs, the honest true tanner
I see plain men by observation,
Of things that alter in the change of times,
Daughter knowledge, and the meanest life,
Proportioned with content sufficiency,
Is merry then the mighty state of Kings.
Now now? what news bring ye sirs,
Where's the Queen?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Her highness and your mother my dread lord,
Are both invited by sir Humphrey bows,
Where they intend to feast and lodge this night,
And do expect your grace's presence there.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Tom Sellinger I have other business;
Astray from you and all my other train,
I met a tanner, such a merry mate,
So frolic, and so full of good conceit,
That I have given my word to be his guest,
because he knows me not to be the King:
Good cousin Howard grudge not at the jest,
But greet my mother and my wife from me,
Bid them be merry, I must have my humour,
Let them both sup and sleep when they see time,
Commend me kindly to sir Humphrey bows,
Tell him at breakfast I will visit him.
This night Tom Sellinger and I must feast
With Hobs the tanner, there plain Ned and Tom.
No King nor Sellinger for a thousand pound.

div.stage: Enter a messenger booted with letters, and kneeling gives them to the King.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: The Queen and Duchess will be discontent,
Because his highness comes not to the feast.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir Humphrey bows may take the most conceit,
But what's the end, the King will have his pleasure?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Good news my boys, Harry the sixth is dead, peruse that letter: sirrah, drink you that, gives his purse, and stay not but post back again for life, and thank my brother Gloster for his news, commend me to him, I'll see him tomorrow night. How like ye it sirs?

div.stage: Exit messenger.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: O passing well my liege, you may be merry for these happy news.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The merrier with our host the tanner Tom,
My lord take you that letter to the ladies,
Bid them be merry with that second course,
And if we see them not before we go,
Pray them to journey easily after us,
We'll post to London, so good night my lord.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Hobs and his daughter Nell.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Come Nell, come daughter, is your hands and your face washed?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.l: I forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Ye must be cleanly I tell ye, for there comes a courtnoll hither tonight , the King's master ships butler, Ned, a spruce youth, but beware ye be not in love nor overtaken
by him, for courtiers be slippery lads.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.l: No forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: God's blessing on thee, that half years schooling at Lichfield, was better to thee then house and land, it has put such manners into thee, I forsooth and no forsooth at every word, ye have a clean smock on. I like your apparel well, is supper ready?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.l: I forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Have we a good barley bagpudding, a piece of fat bacon, a good cow heel, a hard cheese, and a brown loaf.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: All this forsooth, and more, ye shall have a posset, but indeed the rats have spoilt your hard cheese.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Now the devil choke them, so they have eat me a farthing candle the other night.

sp.speaker: Dudgeon within.
sp.l: What master master.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: How now knave, what fairest thou dudgeon?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Here's guests come, where's Helen?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: What guests be they?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.p: A courtnoll, one Ned the King's butcher he says, and his friends too.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Ned the King's butcher? ha, ha, the King's butler, take their horses, and walk them, and bid them come near house, Nell lay the cloth, and clap supper o'th' board.
Mas here's Ned indeed and another misproud ruffian,
Welcome Ned, I like thy honesty, thou keepest promise.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: i'faith honest tanner, I'll ever keep promise with thee, pray thee bid my friend welcome.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: By my troth ye are both welcome to Tamwoorth: friend I know not your name.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My name is Tom Twist?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Believe ye that list: but ye are welcome both, and I like you both well but for one thing.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Nay that I keep to myself, for I sigh to see and think, that pride brings many one to extraction.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pre thee tell us thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Troth I doubt ye ne'er came truly by all these gay rags. 'tis not your bare wages and thin f‚óès ye have of the King, can keep ye thus fine, but either ye must rob the King privily, or his subjects openly, to maintain your probicality.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Thinkest thou so tanner:

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter what I think, come let's go to supper,
What Nell, what dudgeon, where be these folks?
sp.stage: Enter Nell and dudgeon, with a table covered.
sp.l: Daughter bid my friends welcome.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.l: Ye are welcome gentlemen as I may say.

sp.speaker: Sell.
sp.l: I thank ye fair maid.

div.stage: Kiss her both.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A pretty wench be my fay.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: How likest her Ned?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I like her so well, I would ye would make me your son in law.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: And I like thee so well Ned, that hadst thou an occupation, for service is no heritage, a young courtier, an old beggar, I could find in my heart to cast her away upon thee, and if thou wilt forsake the court and turn la‚óèner, or vind thyself to a shoemaker in Lichfield, I'll give thee twenty nobles ready money, with my Nell, and trust thee with a dicker of leather, to set up thy trade.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Ned he offers ye fair, if ye have the grace to take it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He does indeed, Tom, and hereafter I'll tell him more.

sp.speaker: Hob.
